title: Sosban Fach
text:
Sosban Fach (<a href="Welsh%20Language">Welsh</a> for "Little Saucepan") is a traditional Welsh <a href="folk%20music">folk</a> song. It is one of the best-known and most often sung songs in the Welsh language.
The song is based on a verse written by <a href="Richard%20Davies%20%28Mynyddog%29">Mynyddog</a> in 1873 as part of his song "Rheolau yr Aelwyd" ("Rules of the home") — see below. Talog Williams, an accountant from Dowlais, created the song we have today by altering Mynyddog's verse and adding four new verses. The song catalogues the troubles of a harassed housewife.
The song is associated with the <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> club <a href="Llanelli%20RFC">Llanelli RFC</a> and, more recently, the <a href="Scarlets">Scarlets</a> regional rugby side. The association derives from <a href="Llanelli">Llanelli's</a> <a href="Tinning">tin plating</a> industry, which used to tin-plate steel saucepans and other kitchen utensils as a cheap supply to the British public. During the final years of <a href="Stradey%20Park">Stradey Park</a>, the former ground of Llanelli RFC and the Scarlets, the goalposts were adorned with Scarlet saucepans as a tribute to the town's history; the utensils have been transferred to the clubs' new ground, <a href="Parc%20y%20Scarlets">Parc y Scarlets</a>. The Scarlets' official magazine is titled "Sosban".
<a href="Bryn%20Terfel">Bryn Terfel</a> recorded the song on his 2000 album "<a href="We%27ll%20Keep%20a%20Welcome%20%28album%29">We'll Keep a Welcome</a>".

Variations.
This song has been adopted by the fans of the rugby team, the <a href="Scarlets">Llanelli Scarlets</a>. Many English variations can be heard in the stands during rugby matches.

Other media.
Author <a href="Diana%20Wynne%20Jones">Diana Wynne Jones</a> refers to the song several times as 'Calcifer's silly saucepan song' in her book "<a href="Howl%27s%20Moving%20Castle">Howl's Moving Castle</a>".
The Welsh rock band <a href="Man%20%28band%29">Man</a> has a recording of the song on the live album "Back Into the Future", 1973. It is sung by the <a href="Gwalia%20Male%20Choir">Gwalia Male Choir</a>.
